abstract.p: Varied uses of comic book superheroes in advertising noted; photo (Pulse column) (S)

block.p: Run this through your Batcomputer: ''X-Men'' opens July 14. A live-action version of ''The Tick,'' starring Patrick Warburton as the big blue bug, makes its debut in January on Fox. Batman, Superman and Wonder Woman grace boxes of Kraft Macaroni & Cheese. Barbie is dressing like Wonder Woman. Christina Aguilera was last seen wearing a Supergirl shirt on the cover of Rolling Stone. Jet Li is set to play Kato in a big-screen version of ''The Green Hornet.'' A Spiderman movie is spinning into production for a Thanksgiving 2001 release. And a half-dozen more secret-identities-and-groovy-gadgets flicks are in development. Whassup? It's the return of the superhero. Holy do-gooders in tights -- or leather.

Truth, Justice and the Commercial Way

Supershilling superheroes are being tapped to sell everything from fashion clothes to French fizzy water. A vintage black-and-white shot of Superman is part of a television montage ad for Tommy Hilfiger Men -- but don't blink, it goes by faster than a speeding bullet. A live-action Batman (played by Bruce Thomas, not Michael Keaton, Val Kilmer, George Clooney or Adam West) appears in a series of television commercials for OnStar, a car dashboard computer system. Catwoman would have been a natural choice; instead, cartoon versions of Batman and Superman appear with white milk mustaches in recent print ads for the popular ''Got milk?'' campaign. Neither, though, is as refreshing (or as ubiquitous) as ads of the Human Torch reaching off a man's T-shirt toward a bottle of Perrier. This member of the Fantastic Four appears on bus shelters across town and as giveaway Max Racks postcard/stickers.
